DOCNAME: CASE OF WODITSCHKA AND WILFLING v. AUSTRIA
CONCLUSION: Violation of Art. 14+8;Not necessary to examine Art. 8;Non-pecuniary damage - financial award;Costs and expenses award - domestic proceedings;Costs and expenses partial award - Convention proceedings
TEXT: CARDINAL . The first applicant was born in DATE and lives in GPE .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG ( PERSON für PERSON ) convicted the first applicant under LAW of having committed homosexual acts with an adolescent and sentenced him to a fine of ORG CARDINAL ( approximately EUR CARDINAL ) with CARDINAL days’ imprisonment in default . The sentence was suspended on probation . ORG found that , in DATE , the first applicant , who was then DATE , had had about CARDINAL homosexual contacts with a DATE . In determining the sentence the court had regard to the applicant ’s confession and his young age as a mitigating circumstance , as well as to the repetition of the offence as an aggravating circumstance .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG ( Oberlandesgericht ) dismissed the first applicant ’s appeal on points of law , in which he had complained that section CARDINAL of LAW was discriminatory and violated his right to respect for his private life , and in which he had also suggested that ORG request ORG to review the constitutionality of that provision .
CARDINAL . The second applicant was born in DATE and lives in GPE .

CARDINAL . On DATE the Wiener Neustadt Regional Court ordered the second applicant ’s detention on remand on suspicion of having committed homosexual acts with an adolescent contrary to section CARDINAL of LAW .

CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG convicted the second applicant under LAW and sentenced him to CARDINAL months’ imprisonment , CARDINAL of which were suspended on probation . It found that , from DATE until his arrest , the second applicant had a homosexual relationship with a DATE . In determining the sentence the court had regard to the applicant ’s confession as a mitigating circumstance , as well as to the repetition of the offence and a previous conviction as aggravating circumstances .
CARDINAL . On DATE the second applicant was released from detention on remand .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG ( Oberlandesgericht ) dismissed the second applicant ’s appeal on points of law , in which he had complained that section CARDINAL of LAW was discriminatory and violated his right to respect for his private life , and in which he had also suggested that ORG request ORG to review the constitutionality of that provision . Upon ORG appeal it changed the sentence to the effect that CARDINAL out of DATE of imprisonment were suspended on probation .

CARDINAL . Subsequently the second applicant was granted a stay of the execution of his sentence . On DATE he requested a pardon and a further stay of execution pending the decision on his request for pardon . On DATE the ORG granted a further stay of execution .
CARDINAL . On DATE the Federal President , upon the second applicant ’s request , granted him a remission of the remaining sentence .
CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL of LAW , in the version in force at the material time , read as follows :
“ A male person who after attaining DATE fornicates with a person of the same sex who has attained the age of DATE but not the age of CARDINAL shall be sentenced to imprisonment for DATE . ”
CARDINAL . On DATE , upon a request for review made by ORG , ORG found that LAW was unconstitutional .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG decided to repeal LAW . That amendment , published in ORG ( ORG ) no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL , came into force on DATE .

CARDINAL . The ORG notes that the legal situation has remained unchanged since DATE , when it gave its PERSON and PERSON v. GPE judgment ( nos . CARDINAL and CARDINAL , ORG CARDINAL-I ) . For a more detailed description of the law , ORG judgments concerning LAW and the parliamentary debate relating to the issue , it therefore refers to the said judgment ( LAW DATE ) .
